records.title: Thoughts about Event Handling on Android
gained: some time of events (states) shouldnt be stored as state: temp error message, navigation event as it might be repeated (when screen is rotated for example)
solutions: one stream of events, two streams, multiple observers
If we want to notify the View about something just once, we can’t place that data in the ViewState

records.title: Gradle vs Bazel for JVM Projects
gained: ways to improve build time 1) remote build cache of previously compiled modules. 2) incremental builds. 3) distributed build: one module compiles by multiple machines and then combined
remote build cache doesn't offer befirt for single module (monolith) projects, because requires rebuilding all sources from scratch

gradle is focused and optimized for jvm projects, bazel provides wide range of build types, delegating details to particular platform tools like javac. Hence gradle for example has better incremental build time
bazel has *.bazel files per each java package + build.bazel; gradle has just 2 files: build.gradle and setting.gradle => bazel requires significantly more files
gradle provides much better dependencies manemeng and dependencies issues resolution, on bazel side lots of dependencies issues must be resolved manually

records.title: AndroidDevPodcast:114
gained: some app works in unexpected ways on 120hz screens. Mostly because of custom animation low level animation logic > test more + from android 11 it's possible to define hz for your app

dynamic feature module delivery is recommended to be used with app which have heavy libraries which can be extracted into separate module. In particular it can be useful for games, because initial part of game can be very minimal and later stages of game can be downloaded later
onboarding a/b tests result: before 80% of users were skiping onboarding, then 20%. Changed: just pictures and some text, then configuration and setting up of the app
there is library from jitpack to handle screen states of foldable devices
since Android 11 toast changes: callback of hiding/showing, can be showed only when app is in foreground, google recommends to show only texts and no custom views and eventually migrate to snackbar
Android 11: new activity result api, prevous will be deprecated
Open source of samples of using of corotines

records.title: Production best practices: performance and reliability
gained: Gzip compressing can greatly decrease the size of the response body and hence increase the speed of a web app.
Use async api/functions only. Sync might be used on startup. To trace sync api calls use --trace-sync-io command-line flag
console.log and console.error are sync, so no usage in production
use module debug to log handle logging properly in dev environment
use module Winston or Bunyan to log app activity in production
One thing you should not do is to listen for the uncaughtException event as it breaks default behavour, hence process will continue to run despite the exception
Use a tool such as JSHint or JSLint to help you find implicit exceptions
Set NODE_ENV to production: enables caches, less verbose error messages > gread performance improvement
Checking process.env.NODE_ENV cuts performance
In dev start app with cmd, but in production use process manager like PM2
When system crashes/restarts process manager should be started and then app as well by pm
With PM2 clustering might be done without changing code, PM2 will launch several processes per app. App must be stateless.

references.name: Comparing Winston and Bunyan Node.js Logging
Building Robust Node Applications: Error Handling
Asynchronous Error Handling in Express with Promises, Generators and ES7
Upstart Intro, Cookbook and Best Practices
